733454f.title: Transportation - Railroads - New York Central Railroad - Engine and train.
733454f.text:
Transportation: A N. Y. C. R. R. engine and train on Tenth Avenue at W. 39th Street. This thoroughfare was one of those populariy known as "Railroad Avenue" because of their use by the R. R. Co. Subsequent to 1w33, they will use a continuous elevated highway south of this point. Northward an undercut will be utilined. This is a portion of the West Side Improvement Project. For photos, see files under said classification and the various thoroughfares, as Tenth, Eleventh,
and Twelfth Avenues.
About 1930
Views 1-4
P. L. Sperr

710559f-a.text:
Tenth Avenue, west side, from 39th to 40th Streets.
October 31, 193
P.L. Sperr,Photographer.

Tenth Avenue, at and adjoining the N.E. Corner of 39th Street. 5l8 Tenth Avenue,on the right, is the corner house. The centre house, 520 Tenth avenue, 1s a three-story frame house with a
brick front.
1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection,Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 501.
(2)
A rear view of the frame house shown in No. 1.
1932.

712585f-a.text:
440-456 West 39th Street, south side, west from a point east of Tenth Avenue and towards same, showing tenements and a loft building that were subsequently demolished. The factory structure bears No. 448-50 and was occupied by Owen Wards Sons. The low white building partially shown at the right margin is No. 516 Tenth Avenue. This is at the
S.E. corner.
August, 1934
Gift of Samuel Landsman
Arverne. Long Island

Avenue.
March 18, 1935.

712588f-a.text:
West 39th Street, north side, east from Tenth Avenue, showing vacant lots and tenement interspersed. The church structure at No. 451 is a renovated 4 story 'building and is occupied by the Church of St. George (Greek Orthodox). Overhead an aviator is advertising for a popular Fifth Avenue fur house. M.J. Fox & Co.' No. 2 shows details of this view. The McGraw-Hill Bldg.
appears across the roof of the Church in same.
Pe. 10, 1938.
P. L. Sperr,

710555f-a.text:
A two-story frame structure at the rear of 514 Tenth Avenue, adjoining the S.E. corner of 39th Street. This will be demolished
in 1935.
1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 516.

712590f-a.text:
No's. 535 to 529 W. 39th Street, north side, between Eieventh and Tenth Avenues, as viewed northeastward to show beyond the afore-enurerated buildings the new cut contairing the roadbed of the New York Central Railroad. Ap.aratus shown is clearing the rock from same onto a
track to be hauled away.
